physDesc.p: Three pages typewritten in black ink. Mrs. Richard Aldington Bosigram, Pendeen, Cornwall, England is the typed address given for H. D. in the top left corner of the first page. Unsigned. Includes a postscript.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: I have your letter of May 9th. You did not date it, but that is what the postmark says, so I suppose that is right.

I am awfully glad that you agree with me about Richard’s poems. I was so afraid you would not, and I hated to seem disagreeable. I know that what I said about them is true, but I do not think that I can produce any effect on him. I am too far away, and he would probably think me too far removed from the life he is leading to understand his attitude. In fact, that is evidently what he does think, for I have had a letter from him written on May 14th. He says that he is quite willing to delete the dates in "Nights of Love" but he does not seem to want to make any other changes. He says, with reference to the other points: "I think the lines you quote should be clear to the unbiased mind." That seems to settle it, and I do not know what else I can do. It is very good of you to think that I have some influence over him and can help him, but I am afraid I have been away from him too long, and he knows too little about the march of my own work to have very much regard for my opinion. His letter was as nice as it could possibly be, most friendly and sympathetic, but he clings to his own opinion, which is natural, after all.

I do understand how you feel about the criticism, and yet I cannot help thinking that as his guardian angel you would do well to put a veto on some of those poems. I think he will thank you later. But of course that must be for you to decide.

In giving the poems to Brown over my head, he of course took away my authority, and Brown is not a man to stickle at printing anything. His chief business is printing books which other publishers do not want, and he regards himself as emancipated in consequence, and pioneers of emancipation seldom admit the law of taste, and as the publisher is willing to print them as they are, and Richard wants them so printed, I am afraid I have absolutely no authority. I wish I had. I wish I could have got Macmillan to take them, and I wish he could have made the changes. I am also very sorry that he gave them to Brown, for I doubt if they ever see the light of day. Brown has had a book of Fletcher’s for two years, and it is not out yet. Perhaps that last will be the saving of the situation, although now that he has signed the contract, I doubt whether he could get the book back from Brown if he wanted it. I will answer this letter of his of course, but I have no hope of there being any change in his attitude unless you can bring it about.

Are you all alone in Cornwall, or have you some one with you? Do write often. It seems so long since I have seen you all, and now that we have no Anthology to keep us together, there is of course a danger of our drifting apart unless we keep on writing.

I am not surprised that Fletcher sets himself up, as you say. That is what I gathered from his letters. I am afraid his idiosyncrasies are growing on him, and that he has very little future. I will send you my new book when it comes out in the Autumn. I am calling it "Can Grande’s Castle," and I am using Richard’s poem, "At the British Museum," – that is, quotations from it – as my motto. I am not at all sure whether you will like the book as it is all in "polyphonic prose," but I hope you will.
Much love from both Mrs. Russell and me, dear Hilda, and you can count on me always. I wish I could induce Richard to change some of those poems, but you see how it is.
body.postscript: P.S. Did you ever get the article on Richard, Flint, and Lawrence that I sent?
